PSA It's called an Arithmetic Underflow. 

For practical reasons, computers encode numbers as a "number circle" rather than a "number line". Maybe this seems theoretically unsound. But developers do control the size of the circle for each variable. Therefore, they can choose a range larger than the computer realistically needs. E.g. an 8-bit integer (the smallest range) enumerates up to 2^8 = 256 unique values and often specifies a range of either [0, 255] or [-128, 127]. 

Why [0, 255] and not [0, 256]? Because computers count from '0' whereas humans count from '1'. If humans counted from '0', we'd say 2017 was in the 20th century instead of the 21st century. See also [Why numbering should start at zero](https://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/EWD/transcriptions/EWD08xx/EWD831.html) by Dijkstra. 

Why is [-128, 127] unsymmetrical? A naive binary encoding would double-count zero as '-0' and '+0'. But this leads to "5 - 10 = -4". We'd prefer only a _single_ zero. So we pretend '-0' is actually '-1' and tug the remaining negative values over a notch.

I'm 99.9% certain that the Future's Market rune is what's causing this. Before now, the gold value could never be negative, so it's probably stored as an unsigned value (judging from the number, an unsigned 32-bit integer, as the max value that can be represented by one of those is 4,294,967,295 (roughly 4.3 billion))

They obviously changed this in the actual game, but in the replay/spectator client it's probably  still stored the same way. So what's happening is that Ezreal is taking out a loan with Future's Market, putting his gold below 0, and because an unsigned value can't represent negative numbers, it's rolling back round to the maximum possible integer.

To be fair: Kleptomancy might be the only Rune that actually brings him up to par with other ADC's, just to be clear I am not one of you dirty ADC mains. For a while Ezreal has been in a horrid spot since the crit item update for Marksmen, The King of Fapping (Tryndamere), and the Psychopathic Samurai (Yasuo).
